channel.title: Abid Omar
channel.description: Hi. My name is Abid Omar and this is the corner of the web where I write some stuff

item.title: Regulation as a Service
item.author: contact@omarabid.com (Abid Omar)
item.content:encoded: var Component=(()=>{var h=Object.create;var r=Object.defineProperty;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var l=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var u=Object.getPrototypeOf,p=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var s=t=>r(t,"__esModule",{value:!0});var m=(t,e)=>()=>(e||t((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),y=(t,e)=>{s(t);for(var o in e)r(t,o,{get:e[o],enumerable:!0})},g=(t,e,o)=>{if(e&&typeof e=="object"||typeof e=="function")for(let n of l(e))!p.call(t,n)&&n!=="default"&&r(t,n,{get:()=>e[n],enumerable:!(o=c(e,n))||o.enumerable});return t},f=t=>g(s(r(t!=null?h(u(t)):{},"default",t&&t.__esModule&&"default"in t?{get:()=>t.default,enumerable:!0}:{value:t,enumerable:!0})),t);var d=m((j,i)=>{i.exports=_jsx_runtime});var v={};y(v,{default:()=>w,frontmatter:()=>b});var a=f(d()),b={title:"Regulation as a Service",date:"2021-02-01",tags:["Business"],draft:!1,summary:"Can you sell regulation?",images:[],layout:"PostLayout"};function x(t){let e=Object.assign({p:"p",a:"a"},t.components),{wrapper:o}=e,n=(0,a.jsxs)(a.Fragment,{children:[(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://bitstamp.net",children:"Bitstamp"})," recently upped it's KYC game: The exchange now requires a tons of documentation to allow you trading any amount there. To open an account and start trading you need to provide: Your passport, Proof of residence (some utility bill), You trading history (at other exchanges), Sources of funding (documents such as tax slips), and also you need to fill a questionnaire about your trading activity."]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"If you thought this is bad, here is one more: It costs 0.5% to trade on Bitstamp; whether you are a maker or a taker. The industry standard seems to be around 0.2-0.1%. Bitstamp is 5 times more expensive and 10 times more burdensome to trade with. Which really begs the question: Is there any reason for Bitstamp to exist?"}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The answer might be a surprising: Yes"}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["See, centralized exchanges are a dead business. The only reason they exist today is that de-centralized exchanges are still impractical, complicated and very expensive. But this is bound to change: Instantaneous ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Atomic_swap",children:"atomic swaps"})," are mostly theoretical for now, but they will become practical in the future. And much cheaper too."]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"To trade in a centralized exchange, first, you need to send your crypto to the said exchange and entrust its solvency. Then, you can access the pool of liquidity of that exchange, and rely on arbitrage traders to transfer liquidity from other exchanges. Once the trade is completed, you withdraw your converted crypto."}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Things are different in a decentralized landscape: You only send your crypto to execute the trade. This means all the pools of liquidity are possible, and if there exists a good interface to trade with, you should be able to get the best price of all these available pools. Once the trade is settled, you don't need to withdraw your crypto: There is no counter-party risk."}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"This completely flips the story: Most exchanges will have to shutdown eventually. There is no business in being a middle-men for traders, or an arbitrage trader. But Bitstamp will probably survive: It's not exchange after all, it has turned into a regulatory service between crypto, the legacy banking system and the government."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Some players have already got the hint: ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://erikvoorhees.medium.com/no-more-kyc-with-shapeshift-6d95a3e63ddf",children:"Shapeshift has already moved"})," to a decentralized trading system with no KYC. With more pressure from regulators and improved efficiency from DEX exchanges, most of today exchanges will have no business model."]})]});return o?(0,a.jsx)(o,Object.assign({},t,{children:n})):n}var w=x;return v;})(); ;return Component.default;

item.title: Rust as a productive high-level language
item.author: contact@omarabid.com (Abid Omar)
item.content:encoded: var Component=(()=>{var l=Object.create;var r=Object.defineProperty;var d=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var h=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var p=Object.getPrototypeOf,m=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var i=a=>r(a,"__esModule",{value:!0});var u=(a,e)=>()=>(e||a((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),g=(a,e)=>{i(a);for(var n in e)r(a,n,{get:e[n],enumerable:!0})},y=(a,e,n)=>{if(e&&typeof e=="object"||typeof e=="function")for(let s of h(e))!m.call(a,s)&&s!=="default"&&r(a,s,{get:()=>e[s],enumerable:!(n=d(e,s))||n.enumerable});return a},w=a=>y(i(r(a!=null?l(p(a)):{},"default",a&&a.__esModule&&"default"in a?{get:()=>a.default,enumerable:!0}:{value:a,enumerable:!0})),a);var o=u((I,c)=>{c.exports=_jsx_runtime});var b={};g(b,{default:()=>x,frontmatter:()=>N});var t=w(o()),N={title:"Rust as a productive high-level language",date:"2020-11-10",tags:["Rust","Programming"],draft:!1,summary:"High-level productivity with Rust",images:[],layout:"PostLayout"};function f(a){let e=Object.assign({p:"p",a:"a",hr:"hr",pre:"pre",code:"code",span:"span"},a.components),{wrapper:n}=e,s=(0,t.jsxs)(t.Fragment,{children:[(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Rust is often critiqued as a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=24536645",children:"not a very productive"})," programming language. It is true that there is a bit of a learning curve to be able to program in Rust; but beyond that, I think it pays off in productivity; and massively I must say."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"I haven't been using Rust for production much; maybe a bit more than a year. The static type checks means I'm getting much less bugs in my code, and spend considerably less time in debugging. I can safely say that, for me, Rust is more productive than JavaScript, PHP or Python and the margin keeps getting larger as I get more acquainted with the ecosystem."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.hr,{}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["To entice your interest, here is a situation that I handled lately: I have a program that writes logs to ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syslog",children:"syslog"})," and the terminal. The program compiles and functions correctly on my development machine. However, it returned an error when I deployed it to an ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://alpinelinux.org/",children:"Alpine"})," Docker container. Turns out, Alpine doesn't have a running syslog service by default."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Now that's fine, the program functioned correctly. But I don't care much for syslog on deployment since the program is running inside a container. One solution is to remove the syslog ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sink_(computing)",children:"drain"})," but I need that for development. I can use ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/conditional-compilation.html",children:"conditional compilation"}),"; but there is a better option: If syslog fails, for whatever reason, just ignore that and move on."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"So let's take a look at the old code."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.pre,{children:(0,t.jsxs)(e.code,{className:"language-rust code-highlight",children:[(0,t.jsxs)(e.span,{className:"code-line",children:[" ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-purple",children:"let"})," syslog_drain ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"",children:"="})," ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"syslog_drain"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"",children:"?"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:";"}),` `]}),(0,t.jsxs)(e.span,{className:"code-line",children:[" ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-purple",children:"let"})," term_drain ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"",children:"="})," ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"term_drain"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"",children:"?"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:";"}),` `]})]})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["This code creates two logging drains: one for syslog and one for the terminal. It uses the ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://doc.rust-lang.org/edition-guide/rust-2018/error-handling-and-panics/the-question-mark-operator-for-easier-error-handling.html",children:"? operator"})," to evaluate the result. If the function returns an error, execution will stop and the error bubbles back to the top of the program."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["I have no idea how the syslog or any particular drain fails. And honestly, I don't want to get into these details. What I want is to check if there is a failure; and if so ignore that particular drain. Or return a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://docs.rs/slog/2.5.2/slog/struct.Discard.html",children:"Discard drain"}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/result/",children:"Result"})," type and ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"? operator"})," make this particularly easy. So here is the code that does that."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.pre,{children:(0,t.jsxs)(e.code,{className:"language-rust code-highlight",children:[(0,t.jsxs)(e.span,{className:"code-line",children:[" ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-purple",children:"let"})," syslog_drain ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"",children:"="})," ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"syslog_drain"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"."}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"unwrap_or"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"discard_drain"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"",children:"?"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:";"}),` ",(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"term_drain"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"."}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"unwrap_or"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-blue",children:"discard_drain"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:"("}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"",children:"?"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:")"}),(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"text-code-white",children:";"}),` `]})]})}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"And that's it. This code now compiles and runs correctly. If syslog is running, it'll write logs to syslog and the terminal. Otherwise, it'll write logs to the terminal and syslog is skipped. There are no conditions, no complicated checks and it's perfectly readable."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.hr,{}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"There is more to Rust productivity than that. item.title: How complex is modern web development
item.description: Visualizing the complexity of modern web development
item.author: contact@omarabid.com (Abid Omar)
item.content:encoded: var Component=(()=>{var r=Object.create;var l=Object.defineProperty;var o=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var h=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var m=Object.getPrototypeOf,N=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var c=s=>l(s,"__esModule",{value:!0});var t=(s,e)=>()=>(e||s((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),u=(s,e)=>{c(s);for(var a in e)l(s,a,{get:e[a],enumerable:!0})},b=(s,e,a)=>{if(e&&typeof e=="object"||typeof e=="function")for(let d of h(e))!N.call(s,d)&&d!=="default"&&l(s,d,{get:()=>e[d],enumerable:!(a=o(e,d))||a.enumerable});return s},g=s=>b(c(l(s!=null?r(m(s)):{},"default",s&&s.__esModule&&"default"in s?{get:()=>s.default,enumerable:!0}:{value:s,enumerable:!0})),s);var p=t((v,i)=>{i.exports=_jsx_runtime});var j={};u(j,{default:()=>x,frontmatter:()=>f});var n=g(p()),f={title:"How complex is modern web development",date:"2020-10-26",tags:["Web","Programming"],draft:!1,summary:"Visualizing the complexity of modern web development",images:[],layout:"PostLayout"};function y(s){let e=Object.assign({p:"p",a:"a",h1:"h1",span:"span",ul:"ul",li:"li",strong:"strong",code:"code",em:"em",img:"img",pre:"pre"},s.components),{wrapper:a}=e,d=(0,n.jsxs)(n.Fragment,{children:[(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Modern web development is ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.vrk.dev/2019/07/11/why-is-modern-web-development-so-complicated-a-long-yet-hasty-explanation-part-1/",children:"notorious for being complicated"})," and a source of heated discussions around the web. Because of the endless new libraries and inter-mingled dependencies, making a simple web application has never been this complicated."]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["To illustrate, a new ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app",children:"create-react-app"})," with TypeScript, sass, and bootstrap consumes around 536M of dependencies. That's a half gigabyte to run a boilerplate web page: It's beyond insanity! Is this complexity self-inflicted, or an outcome of a complex surface?"]}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"To find out, I set to create the development and build environments from scratch."}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"the-requirements",children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#the-requirements","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"The Requirements"]}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"First, let's set my requirements for the development environment and the final build."}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.ul,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Optimize for production"}),": Typically, the production build will generate 3 files: ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"index.html"}),", ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"javascript.js"})," and ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"style.css"})," and a ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"resources"})," directory for files like images or fonts. Since I'm building ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-page_application",children:"SPA"}),"s, I don't expect to have other web pages."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"One step"}),": A single step (command) to make a final build of the web app. The same for kick-starting the development environment."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"TypeScript"}),"/",(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Sass"}),": These are personal preferences. TypeScript is recommended for large applications and Sass is nice to have."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Live Reload"}),": Changes automatically detected, and should trigger a re-build and refresh the browser."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"React"}),", ",(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Bootstrap"}),", ",(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Vuejs"})," or ",(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Not"}),": Should be able to add React, Bootstrap, Vuejs or any other libraries. But should also be able to create the app without any dependencies; so no assumptions of frameworks."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Minimal"}),": Only include what we use; no more."]}),` `]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"the-available-solutions",children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#the-available-solutions","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"The available solutions"]}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"There is an excess of options, any choice is going to be driven by personal preferences. I try to reason below what I picked."}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.ul,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"gulp"}),": ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://gulpjs.com/",children:"gulp"})," is a build tool that pipelines resources and transforms them. I like the idea of pipelining as it gives the flexibility to integrate with ",(0,n.jsx)(e.em,{children:"any"})," program."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"webpack"}),": ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://webpack.js.org/",children:"webpack"})," is primarily a module ",(0,n.jsx)(e.em,{children:"bundler"})," that could be used as a build tool. I find gulp superior as a build tool, and webpack superior as a bundler/transpiler. So I mixed both."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"npm"}),": yarn is the hot new thing for package management, but npm did catch up."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.li,{children:[` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"browser-sync"}),": ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://browsersync.io",children:"Browsersync"})," is quite advanced and is very configurable. It also plays nicely with gulp."]}),` `]}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"If this seems complicated, you don't know the half of it. There are many other plugins to use with gulp and webpack; and TypeScript is quite a challenge to get it to compile on reasonable performance."}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The diagram below is actually a simplification of the whole workflow."}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/modern-web-dev/fk7oKCMeeZoRAXM5myvEBT0xspap.png",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/modern-web-dev/fk7oKCMeeZoRAXM5myvEBT0xspap.png",alt:"workflow.png"})})}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"so-how-did-we-do",children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#so-how-did-we-do","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"So how did we do?"]}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The final boilerplate can be found in this Github repository: ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://github.com/omarabid/front-root",children:"front-root"}),". It's a serious question especially if you are looking to get in or out of the market in these times."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["On a linear scale, the ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASDAQ_Composite",children:"Nasdaq Composite"})," looks like this."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/zero-rates-world/h3MBaJ9YNS81ukfc4BZSTi0xspap.png",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/zero-rates-world/h3MBaJ9YNS81ukfc4BZSTi0xspap.png",alt:"Nasdaq index"})})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Although the ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dow_Jones_Industrial_Average",children:"Dow Jones"})," is looking more conservative, skeptics would argue that the market should go down. After all, we are about to enter one of the worst economic crisis due to the Coronarvirus; and unemployment numbers are just terrifying. But the stock market doesn't seem to think so."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Which begs the question: ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"Are we in a bubble?"})]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"how-are-stocks-priced-anyway",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#how-are-stocks-priced-anyway","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"How are stocks priced anyway?"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["To argue whether the market is overpriced, we need to figure out how to price stocks. If we know how much a particular company is worth, we should be able to reason about its stock price. Stocks, like many other ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset",children:"assets"}),", pay a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dividend",children:"dividend"}),". A stock, in an efficient market, is worth its future dividends combined."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["With this simplification, we can calculate a fair price for the company ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," assuming we know how much it is going to pay in dividends in the future."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," fair price = dividend 2020 + dividend 2021 + ... + dividend 2065"]}),` `]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Our model calculates the fair price of ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"}),". If ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," is trading below our model price, we buy. If ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," is trading above our model price, we sell. This is a very straightforward ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitrage",children:"arbitrage"}),"; if you are able to accurately predict how much the company will pay in dividends. For the purpose of this article, we'll assume that is true for our imaginary company ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"first-complication-inflation",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#first-complication-inflation","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"First complication: Inflation"]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"With such a solid framework to price stocks, we can now make a lot of money. Comes the first complication: Inflation. It's easy to be mislead that our strategies are making a profit, when in reality it's inflation that is driving them. Again, to simplify, we are going to assume that we can accurately predict the inflation rate."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["With that, let's look at our first scenario: The yearly inflation rate is 10%. Our research office had predicted that the company ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," is going to pay $10 in dividends by the end of the year and then ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissolution_(law)",children:"dissolve"})," with no assets left."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"According to our model, the company should trade at the sum of its future dividends."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," fair price = 2021 dividends = $10"]}),` `]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["But with inflation, $10 today is worth less than the same $10 in the future. We know that ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," is going to pay $10 in the future regardless of the inflation rate. We need to adjust our price to account for inflation."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," fair price (adjusted for inflation) = $9.09"]}),` `]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["By the end of the year, ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," should be trading at $10; but that ",(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"future"})," $10 has as much purchasing power as ",(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"today's"})," $9.09. This adjustment ensures that we do not lose money due to inflation. ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"If we predict high inflation in the future, we should price this particular stock down, not up"}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.hr,{}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The next scenario has a twist: An imaginary company ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"AAPL"})," produces apples and pays dividends in real apples instead of dollars. Today, an apple cost $1; and with inflation an apple will cost $1.1 by the end of the year. The company ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"AAPL"})," is going to pay 10 apples in dividends by year-end, and also dissolve. What's the fair price for ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"AAPL"}),"?"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Surprisingly, it's $10. Think about it this way: ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"AAPL"})," is going to pay 10 apples in dividends worth $10 ",(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"today"}),". That is how much ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"AAPL"})," is worth ",(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"today"}),". By the end of the year, the apples are worth $11 and ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"AAPL"})," should trade at $11."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"This particular stock can protect you against inflation, but only if you buy at reasonable (non-inflated) prices. This means, for this particular stock, inflation has no effects on the price. It doesn't matter how much apples are going to be worth in the future, you are pricing the stock today."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"What about deflation?"})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deflation",children:"Deflation"})," is the reverse of inflation. For stocks that generate dollars, deflation should price them up. For stocks that generate apples-like goods, it doesn't matter; as with inflation."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"second-complication-interest-rate",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#second-complication-interest-rate","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Second Complication: Interest rate"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Let's forget about inflation and deflation. In this part, we'll assume that dollars hold stable values, regardless. Our investor has $10 and is looking to put his money to work; he also has no viable use of his money. Unluckily, there is a single company to invest in; ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"}),". The company will pay $10 in dividend guaranteed by the end of the year and then dissolve."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Comes the ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Reserve",children:"Fed"}),": The Federal Reserve has announced that it is guaranteeing all of the government issued ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_bond",children:"bonds"}),". This means that these bonds are risk-free since the Fed can ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/federally-guaranteed-obligation.asp",children:"print its way out of a loan"}),". These bonds pay 10% yearly and our investor can buy them."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Our investor looks at his trading terminal: He can buy the bonds at $10; and get $11 by the end of the year. Or he can buy ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," and gets $10 by the end of the year. With this new choice (government bond), our investor is unlikely to buy ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," at $10/share. It makes more sense to buy the government bond as it has better ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yield_(finance)",children:"yield"}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["For ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," to make sense, it has to pay (yield) at least as well as the government bond. For that, ",(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"today"}),", ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FANG"})," should trade at $9.09 to be of good value for our investor. The market is now at equilibrium: both viable investments now generate an equal yield: 10%."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.hr,{}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"The trade of the century"})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["With government intervention (which is acting similar to inflation; if you noticed), our investor should be careful about the ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupon_(finance)",children:"coupon"})," for these bonds. In the future, these are going to determine how he prices stocks. And how much can this interest rate affect the market? ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"Hold your horses"}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Let's analyze this scenario where we have these two companies: ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FAST"})," and ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"SLOW"}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Ticker"}),": ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FAST"})," Company will pay $10 guaranteed by the end of the year and then dissolve. ",(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Ticker"}),": ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"SLOW"})," Company will pay $10 guaranteed after 100 years and then dissolve."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["It might seem counter-intuitive but with ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"no inflation and no government bonds"}),", both of these investments are equivalent for an investor with a 100 year investment horizon. This assumes that our investor has no other viable use of his money. On a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"rational"})," market, under these conditions, both should trade at the same price: $10. After all, if there are no other viable investment, the investor who put his money in ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FAST"})," is going to hold cash for the next 99 years; ending with a similar yield to ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"SLOW"}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"So what happens if the government introduces a 100 year bond with a 10% interest rate payout? Let's do the math."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Ticker"}),": ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FAST"})," Government yield: %10 Fair price: $9.09 ",(0,t.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Ticker"}),": ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"SLOW"})," Government yield: %1,378,061 Fair price: $0.000725"]}),` `]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["While the government bond did affect the ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"FAST"})," company slightly, the price for ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"SLOW"})," practically evaporated. Both companies are still the same companies and are going to deliver on their promises. Nothing has changed and yet the prices made it seem like the apocalypse is upon us."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"If we start from a situation where government is paying interest and then decides to do it no more; prices are going to go up. This uplift is going to be much more noticeable for stocks with a very far-off payout. A smart or well-connected investor will buy these stocks and then watch his portfolio skyrocket."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/zero-rates-world/knnrY2r4JLNpMeSYrhFW7j0xspap.png",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/zero-rates-world/knnrY2r4JLNpMeSYrhFW7j0xspap.png",alt:"rates.png"})})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"brave-new-world",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#brave-new-world","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Brave New World"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Intelligent_Investor",children:"The intelligent investor"})," is a recommended reading for people looking to generate yield. It establishes a framework for investing that we summarized above: If bonds have better yield, then buy bonds and sell stocks; and vice-versa. However, low interest rates might stick for a while: Japan has been on this regime for over 20 years and it's unlikely to change in the future."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/zero-rates-world/5rWFJWaQdEi5FtKxBfXLo90xspap.png",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/zero-rates-world/5rWFJWaQdEi5FtKxBfXLo90xspap.png",alt:"Screen Shot 2020-09-08 at 4.22.47 PM.png"})})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["If you are ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"an intelligent investor"}),", you might think that investors buying or holding assets in these times are crazy. Actually, they could be the most careful. For an investor with a long-time investment horizon, has no viable use of his money and is expecting a regime change to zero or negative interest rate; the best trade is to either buy or hold your assets."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["In a negative rate world, it's safe to throw ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"The intelligent investor"})," book. ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Price%E2%80%93earnings_ratio",children:"P/E ratios"})," make more sense in a high interest rate world since companies are competing with the risk-free rate. If bonds are generating an income, you want your stocks to generate a comparable dividend. This is the effect that prices far-payoff stocks down."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["If Tech companies are perceived to have a very far pay-off, then they become the most affected by a zero or negative interest rate. In that sense, investors are not buying up these stocks; they are just pricing them to the new reality. With ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Monetary_Theory",children:"Modern Money Theory"})," on the rise, it's possible that negative rates become the norm; especially that MMT response to inflation is to raise taxes not the interest rate."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["MMT is the idea that money should be available to anyone who ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"deserves"})," it (ie: If you want to make a transaction, you should have liquidity available). You can think of interest rates as a rent payment to people who own the cash. It's not fair to not be able to conduct business without going through a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rentier",children:"rentier"}),". On the other hand, today's retirees have benefited from this high-yield to generate massive wealth in the last century by the power of compound interest. This makes them the suitable suitors to buy today's assets which will become inaccessible for most of the workforce once prices adjust."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The upside of MMT and 0% interest rates is that it allows a whole set of businesses to become viable. Businesses with a 1% yield are not viable with a high interest rate as it makes more sense to just buy bonds. People who can generate yield will thrive, since the expected market yield is zero. It's still a question whether this will benefit mainstream; or a bunch of tech companies that have a monopoly of tech and innovation. In this kinda world, tech and innovation are the only possible venues to generate yield, since money is widely available for anything else."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"It's possible that MMT becomes the very worst enemy it's trying to protect us from; creating a situation where wealth mobility is practically impossible. After all, the road to hell is paved with good intentions."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"so-are-we-in-a-bubble",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#so-are-we-in-a-bubble","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"So are we in a bubble?"]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Maybe, but it's also possible that these high prices are here to stay. Since the Euro zone is also on a negative diet; the market reads as follow: Europe is dying (stocks have not risen by negative rates), the Dow Jones will fare better; and the Nasdaq is taking over the world in the medium-long term. If you don't like that reading, maybe it's time to sell."})]});return n?(0,t.jsx)(n,Object.assign({},i,{children:o})):o}var k=b;return v;})(); ;return Component.default;

item.title: Apple's Hell
item.author: contact@omarabid.com (Abid Omar)
item.content:encoded: var Component=(()=>{var h=Object.create;var n=Object.defineProperty;var d=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var p=Object.getPrototypeOf,u=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var r=a=>n(a,"__esModule",{value:!0});var m=(a,e)=>()=>(e||a((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),g=(a,e)=>{r(a);for(var i in e)n(a,i,{get:e[i],enumerable:!0})},w=(a,e,i)=>{if(e&&typeof e=="object"||typeof e=="function")for(let o of c(e))!u.call(a,o)&&o!=="default"&&n(a,o,{get:()=>e[o],enumerable:!(i=d(e,o))||i.enumerable});return a},f=a=>w(r(n(a!=null?h(p(a)):{},"default",a&&a.__esModule&&"default"in a?{get:()=>a.default,enumerable:!0}:{value:a,enumerable:!0})),a);var l=m((x,s)=>{s.exports=_jsx_runtime});var v={};g(v,{default:()=>k,frontmatter:()=>y});var t=f(l()),y={title:"Apple's Hell",date:"2020-08-18",tags:["Apple","Review"],draft:!1,summary:"Apple's issues",images:[],layout:"PostLayout"};function b(a){let e=Object.assign({p:"p",a:"a",h1:"h1",span:"span",img:"img",blockquote:"blockquote",em:"em",code:"code"},a.components),{wrapper:i}=e,o=(0,t.jsxs)(t.Fragment,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"My journey with Apple's products began roughly 6 years ago. I've been using Windows ever since I started using computers; with brief stunts on Linux. The transition, back then, seemed like a straightforward choice. I didn't have the time to fight and learn Linux. I just needed software and hardware that worked. Apple's ecosystem stroke a balance between getting things done, having reliable hardware and still having room for customization."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS_X_Mavericks",children:"Mavericks"})," was my first introduction to ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacOS",children:"OS X"}),". The OS was fast, seamless and well refined; backups, encryption, and mail just worked with a few clicks. Things, however, haven't been that orderly as of late. macOS has been diverging from its origins as a developer's OS and on track to become a mainstream OS; and hardware build quality is not as good as it used to be. I'm still very happy with the iPhone but not quite sure about macOS and the Macbook lineup. I have also, to a certain degree, outgrown the macOS ecosystem. I needed a greater deal of customization, a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiling_window_manager",children:"tiling window manager"}),", and needed less slick gadgets and zappy notifications."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["My macOS setup was simple, flexible and quite common. I had a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://support.apple.com/kb/SP776?locale=en_US",children:'15" 2018 Macbook Pro'})," that is my primary machine plugged to three monitors on desk. I also had an older ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://support.apple.com/kb/SP704?locale=en_US",children:'15" 2014 Macbook Pro'})," as a backup machine; just in case the primary machine went down. I didn't have second thoughts about using a laptop as a desktop replacement; that seemed what everyone else is doing."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"swollen-batteries",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#swollen-batteries","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Swollen batteries"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Much like the rest of world, I was stuck at home during March and April due to a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019",children:"confinement order"}),". I didn't need to unplug my Macbook during that time, and it being placed behind three big monitors made it unnoticeable. I didn't observe any weirdness or effects on performance and there were no alerts until I unplugged it and discovered an unpleasant surprise."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/apple-hell/nZDzPJ5H2vxmooTntiuwmS0xspap.jpg",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/apple-hell/nZDzPJ5H2vxmooTntiuwmS0xspap.jpg",alt:"Macbook Pro battery"})})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"the battery is still in good condition according to macOS"}),` `]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The laptop was purchased a year and four months ago; its warranty has expired and I was aware that I'd have to repair it on my expense. What I wasn't aware of, however, is how expensive to repair the 2018 line or how hard it is to replace its battery. iFixit has a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/MacBook+Pro+15-Inch+Touch+Bar+2018+Battery+Replacement/122269",children:"guide"})," on how to do it and it's a real struggle. The process is a 66 steps that will take a professional anything from one to three hours and requires special tools. It's not a process that I feel comfortable doing on my own."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["There are no Apple stores where I live, so I paid a couple ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"Apple Authorized service providers"})," a visit. I got quoted around $800 for the battery replacement and 2-3 months repair time. Apparently, they can't replace the battery but the whole casing. They also need to order the new casing and have it shipped which can take considerable time. That did leave a bad taste: not being able to replace the battery might be acceptable if the upside is a slimmer laptop but the fee to get it serviced is simply ridiculous."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["It doesn't seem that I am the only one facing this ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://forums.macrumors.com/threads/macbook-pro-2018-swelling.2208695/",children:"issue"}),", though it seems the people who had the issue are also using the Macbook as a desktop replacement with multiple monitors plugged; so maybe there is something to that. People who have access to an Apple store seemed to have better luck of getting it fixed for free; however, for the rest of us, it's not that lucky."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Interestingly, during that time, Apple released a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2020/05/apple-introduces-new-macbook-battery-management-with-macos-catalina-10-15-5/",children:"macOS update"})," for battery management. The timing is suspicious, but it might have been just coincidental. We do know that batteries for the ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://support.apple.com/15-inch-macbook-pro-battery-recall",children:"2015 lineup had a problem"})," with swelling and there is a ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://support.apple.com/15-inch-macbook-pro-battery-recall",children:"replacement program"}),". But they only recognized that in 2019, so do not hold your breath."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Getting the laptop handled on short notice being unlikely, I moved to my second plan: using the older one as backup."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"time-machine-woes",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#time-machine-woes","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Time Machine Woes"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The most important lesson that I have learned from this wreck was: It's not enough to do backups, you also have to test that they do work; probably regularly. I didn't do that and I was caught by surprise that ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_Machine_(macOS)",children:"Time Machine"})," backups did not work in accordance to my expectations."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["My expectation was that Time Machine will backup ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"all"})," files. By ",(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"all"})," files, I thought it did a clone of my Hard Drive; and when restored, it'll restore an identical image of the previous system. That is, I'd have a replica of my system configuration, my browser history, sites that I logged on to, etc... Unluckily, that's not the case. Time Machine ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://apple.stackexchange.com/a/25833/58703",children:"do ignore files"}),"; and getting it to do a real system clone appears to be a considerable headache (if possible); especially that I didn't want to operate the hazardous laptop for extended periods of time."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"But does these arbitrarily seeming exclusions matter? Yes, they do. The system was functional but I was not able to run several apps and scripts that I have installed and manually configured. Docker was also broken. I did find all of my files but these were already backed up in iCloud; I was mainly after getting a replica of my other laptop."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"icloud-troubles",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#icloud-troubles","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"iCloud Troubles"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["With a functioning system, I was happy to at least have my files there; even though some stuff is not functioning correctly. But for some reason, the system slowed to a crawl and fans were running at full speed. A process named ",(0,t.jsx)(e.code,{children:"bird"})," was consuming pretty much all of my CPU power; restarting the system or trying to stop it didn't work as it'll spawn again."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The process, apparently, belongs to ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://discussions.apple.com/thread/6606275",children:"iCloud Drive"}),". It's not clear what iCloud is trying to do here, but my wild guess is that iCloud is checking that files on the local drive matches the ones on the cloud. If that's the case, it's probably calculating a checksum for the local files and comparing it to the checksum in the cloud. It's not clear what triggered iCloud, but that might be a consequence of some of the files that Time Machine missed."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"A couple hours later, iCloud is still brewing. There are no progress indicators, so it's not clear how long such a process would take but with hundreds of thousands of files, it might possibly take days?"}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"With restoring the old system becoming an exasperating process, I decided to start from a blank slate. After all, if I was going to fix a broken system might as well just build it again."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"backward-compatibility",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#backward-compatibility","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Backward compatibility"]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["For a new re-install, your 2014 Macbook Pro will install not the latest but the original operating system version. That is, for the 2014 Macbook Pro, you first install Mavericks, and then upgrade to the latest system. That was interesting, since you can't downgrade your system later; and also, you can't upgrade to any system other than the latest. So if you are in this situation, you have Mavericks hardware, you lost your backup, and you need ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS_X_El_Capitan",children:"El Capitain"})," instead of ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacOS_Catalina",children:"Catalina"}),"; I'm not sure if you can do that."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["There is a list of exceptions/rules under ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT204904",children:"macOS Recovery exceptions"})," that will determine which version you can install depending on your hardware and last installed version. Unfortunately, you can't ",(0,t.jsxs)(e.a,{href:"https://apple.stackexchange.com/a/309400/58703",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.em,{children:"simply"})," install a particular version of macOS"]}),"."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Mavericks was a bit of fresh air, though. It was pretty fast, and it didn't have useless features that I didn't need. But then, I stumbled upon another problem: ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backward_compatibility",children:"Backward compatibility"}),". If you have been upgrading your macOS system consistently, you might have missed that Apple is a bad steward of backward compatibility; with probably the one exception of no longer supporting ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2018/01/apple-prepares-macos-users-for-discontinuation-of-32-bit-app-support/",children:"32-bit applications"})," which should have broke most of your games."]}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["These are things that you can turn a blind eye on until they come later and bite you hard. For Mavericks, it didn't have an ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AirDrop#Transfer_between_a_Mac_and_an_iOS_device",children:"interoperable Airdrop"})," with iOS. So I wasn't able to upload photos from my iPhone to the laptop. Maybe I should use Bluetooth? Tough luck, the iPhone doesn't support ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.reddit.com/r/iphone/comments/ar7yd4/sending_photo_from_iphone_to_android_with/",children:"sending a photo"})," over Bluetooth. Once you leave Apple walled garden, you are pretty much screwed."]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Needless to say, I was not able to get lots of applications running like Skype, RescueTime, Fork. They all require the latest version of macOS and do not support older versions."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"moving-forward",children:[(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#moving-forward","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Moving forward"]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"I started having headaches with macOS last year. The Parental Control feature checks every URL you ping, and thus slowed down even local development which took me a week to figure out what process what slowing traffic. With macOS slowly diverging from a developer friendly OS to a mainstream, iPhone-like one, it's time to move on. Here is what the next update of macOS will look like."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/apple-hell/dc5LRFprRqK1kpdQEptrWE0xspap.jpg",children:(0,t.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/apple-hell/dc5LRFprRqK1kpdQEptrWE0xspap.jpg",alt:"macOS Big Sur"})})}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The new macOS is looking more like iOS"}),` `]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"I can understand Apple's perspective; after all, a mainstream market is larger and more profitable than a developer's only market. Creative people will still use Apple products regardless and people developing for macOS/iOS will always depend on the Apple ecosystem. So it might workout profitably for them."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Don't get me wrong, macOS is still a very good OS. I'll probably keep using it in combination to the phone to do regular browsing, mail, documents and other miscellaneous stuff; probably pick an Air instead of a Pro."}),` `,(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["For development, I took the plunge and built a box and installed ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.archlinux.org/",children:"ArchLinux"}),". An ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.amd.com/en/products/cpu/amd-ryzen-7-3700x",children:"AMD Ryzen 3700X"}),", 32 GB of RAM, ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.nvidia.com/en-me/geforce/graphics-cards/gtx-1650-super/",children:"Nvidia GTX 1650 Super"})," and an 256 GB ",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NVM_Express",children:"NVMe drive"})," cost roughly $1.000. Not that far from the cost of repairing a Macbook battery!"]}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"I was surprised how easy it is to setup ArchLinux on a randomly picked box; most of the hardware just worked out of the box; but it's still early to judge the experience as I'm only two months in."}),` `,(0,t.jsx)(e.p,{children:"But that's a talking point for another day!"})]});return i?(0,t.jsx)(i,Object.assign({},a,{children:o})):o}var k=b;return v;})(); ;return Component.default;

item.title: Examining the complex web of USD stable coins
item.description: A brief look on some USD stable coins
item.author: contact@omarabid.com (Abid Omar)
item.content:encoded: var Component=(()=>{var h=Object.create;var s=Object.defineProperty;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var o=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var d=Object.getPrototypeOf,p=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var t=n=>s(n,"__esModule",{value:!0});var u=(n,e)=>()=>(e||n((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),g=(n,e)=>{t(n);for(var i in e)s(n,i,{get:e[i],enumerable:!0})},b=(n,e,i)=>{if(e&&typeof e=="object"||typeof e=="function")for(let r of o(e))!p.call(n,r)&&r!=="default"&&s(n,r,{get:()=>e[r],enumerable:!(i=c(e,r))||i.enumerable});return n},y=n=>b(t(s(n!=null?h(d(n)):{},"default",n&&n.__esModule&&"default"in n?{get:()=>n.default,enumerable:!0}:{value:n,enumerable:!0})),n);var m=u((U,l)=>{l.exports=_jsx_runtime});var S={};g(S,{default:()=>w,frontmatter:()=>f});var a=y(m()),f={title:"Examining the complex web of USD stable coins",date:"2020-06-05",tags:["Crypto","Defi"],draft:!1,summary:"A brief look on some USD stable coins",images:[],layout:"PostLayout"};function N(n){let e=Object.assign({p:"p",a:"a",h1:"h1",span:"span",em:"em",blockquote:"blockquote",strong:"strong",math:"math",semantics:"semantics",mrow:"mrow",mn:"mn",mi:"mi",annotation:"annotation",mo:"mo",h2:"h2"},n.components),{wrapper:i}=e,r=(0,a.jsxs)(a.Fragment,{children:[(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["In late 2014, Tether made a new innovation in the Fintech space: A USD stable coin. The idea is to use Blockchain tech (",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.omnilayer.org",children:"OmniLayer"})," using the Bitcoin network) to move USD as a token. The collateral USD is held at USD-denominated bank accounts. The person who owns the token has claim to the USD, and should be able to reclaim it back as regular dollars."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Tether has since made staggering growth. It claims a colossal ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://coinmarketcap.com/currencies/tether/",children:"$9bn market cap"})," (or the amount they should be holding in US dollars) and is used by several Bitcoin exchanges. The company has drawn lots of criticism: Its relation to Bitfinex is not fully transparent, it has failed at particular moments to hold the 1:1 peg, been the subject of ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-30/crypto-exchange-bitfinex-tether-said-to-get-subpoenaed-by-cftc",children:"subpeonas"})," and ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.coindesk.com/new-york-attorney-general-calls-bitfinexs-legal-stance-deeply-perverse-in-new-filing",children:"lawsuits"}),"; and countless ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.kalzumeus.com/2019/10/28/tether-and-bitfinex/",children:"conspiracy theories"}),". Its last account audits dates from ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://tether.to/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/FSS1JUN18-Account-Snapshot-Statement-final-15JUN18.pdf",children:"June 2018"}),"; so it's safe to say that Tether has failed to produce reliable audits."]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Arguably, this prompted the launch of several new stable coins that promised more transparency, better regulation and guaranteed convertibility. But in our brave new world of negative (or near zero) interest rates; and with transaction fees going to ledger miners (Bitcoin or Ethereum), this raises questions around the business model of such ventures; especially with the associated regulatory costs for running this financial scheme."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"coinbase-usdc",children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#coinbase-usdc","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,a.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Coinbase USDC"]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:['Started in October 2018, USDC by Coinbase promises stable value by having USDC backed in USD bank accounts. As the landing page explains: "',(0,a.jsx)(e.em,{children:"Each USDC is backed by one US dollar, which is held in a bank account."}),'"']}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["USDC is run by ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.coinbase.com/usdc",children:"Coinbase"}),"; or ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.circle.com/en/usdc",children:"Circle"}),". Depending on which landing page you land on first. But if you read a bit more, it seems more of a joint venture they called ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.centre.io/usdc",children:"CENTRE"})," which credits both parties to USDC."]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"USDC has around $700mn in market cap but it's relatively illiquid compared to USDT on the exchanges where it's trading. Which means you'll incur high spread costs if you were to buy or sell it. You can redeem it at full face value in Coinbase, though."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["USDC is audited by ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_Thornton_International",children:"Grant Thornton"})," which is a well known audit firm. That's important since the audit veracity is as good as the reputation of the audit firm. USDC publishes monthly reports, so I picked the ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.centre.io/pdfs/attestation/grant-thornton_circle_usdc_reserves_20200515.pdf",children:"last one"})," to read."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The report is basically an assertion from Circle; and Grant Thornton expressing an ",(0,a.jsx)(e.em,{children:"opinion"})," that the assertion is, in fact, correct."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Circle Internet Financial, Inc.\u2019s management is responsible for its assertion. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Reserve Account Information in the accompanying Reserve Account Report based on our examination."}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The assertion is Circle holding enough USD to cover for the USDC token they have issued. But there is a bit of a word salad in the report."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Those standards require that we plan and perform the examination to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the Reserve Account Information in the accompanying Reserve Account Report is correctly stated, ",(0,a.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"based on the criteria set forth in the Reserve Account Report"}),", in all material respects."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"There are only two Criteria. The second is a bit interesting."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["US Dollars held in custody accounts are the total balances in accounts held by the Company at federally insured US depository institutions and ",(0,a.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"in approved investments on behalf of the USDC holders"})," at the Report Date and Time."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["So USDC might not be backed by US dollars in regular banks but, instead, by ",(0,a.jsx)(e.em,{children:"approved investments"}),"; whatever that means. But how do USDC holders approve these investments? That must be something that could be slipped in the ToS."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["USDC is fully backed by U.S. Dollars or ",(0,a.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"equivalent assets"})," held by Circle with its U.S. banking partners in segregated accounts, on behalf of, and for the benefit of, Users. This means for every USDC issued by Circle and remaining in circulation, Circle will hold on behalf of Users one U.S. Dollar in its bank account(s) or other approved investments"]}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Circle agrees to take reasonable care in maintaining the established value of U.S. Dollar funds provided by you, and ",(0,a.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"you agree Circle is free to use the funds provided for its own purposes"})," prior to redemption subject to the terms of this Agreement."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["When you wire fiat funds into our system, we deposit those funds with one of our banking partners. In the future, ",(0,a.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"Circle may also invest these fiat funds in highly-liquid, AAA-rated fixed income securities"}),"."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"We have been going in circles (pun intended); but if you want the basic gist: Circle is a trading desk and using USDC as capital for trading. They claim that they are only trading/holding AAA-rated fixed income securities, which should be relatively low risk."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"the-paxos-gang",children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#the-paxos-gang","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,a.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"The Paxos gang"]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Binance and Houbi, both, have their own unique USD stable coin. Or so I thought. At a closer inspection, they are all the using the ",(0,a.jsx)(e.em,{children:"Paxos Standard"}),". ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.paxos.com/",children:"Paxos"})," is a fintech company that is ",(0,a.jsx)(e.em,{children:"building infrastructure to enable movement between physical and digital assets"}),"."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Both Binance and Huobi audits are performed by ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.withum.com/",children:"Withum"}),". Which is the same auditor that Paxos is using. The firm is new to me but looking at their website, they seem to be well established in the U.S. While Huobi seems to be working with ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/stable-universal-partners-with-paxos-and-huobi-to-launch-new-stablecoin-husd-300886646.html",children:"Stable Universal limited"})," and Paxos to issue HUSD; Binance directly refers you to Paxos website for monthly attestations."]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The gist is that Binance is holding USD at Paxos. While Huobi is holding USD at Stable Universal Limited which might hold the US dollars itself or at Paxos."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Binance USD market cap is at From their ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://real-time-attest.trustexplorer.io/information-and-disclosure-language",children:"about page"})]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Second, is a system that utilizes Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) to collect near-real-time data from each trust company or banking partner that is charged with custody of each TrueCurrency\u2019s holders\u2019 fiat deposits. This system aggregates the total balances from each escrow partner and presents it on the right-hand portion of the screen."}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["That's pretty impressive, if true. The audit report does mention, however, that TrueUSD might be holding its reserves in ",(0,a.jsx)(e.em,{children:"highly liquid investments"})," of sufficient credit quality; though it doesn't clarify the minimum rating for such securities."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["The USD balance held in escrow accounts are the total balances in accounts held by TrueCoin, LLC at federally insured U.S. depository institutions and a Hong Kong depository institution for the benefit ofthe TUSD token holders as agreed to within the escrow agreements. The USD balance includes USD cash and cash equivalents that include ",(0,a.jsx)(e.strong,{children:"short-term, highly liquid investments of sufficient credit quality"})," that are readily convertible to known amounts of cash. Cash equivalents are recorded at cost which approximates the fair value, or cash value."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.h1,{id:"small-players",children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#small-players","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,a.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Small Players"]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.h2,{id:"gemini-usd",children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#gemini-usd","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,a.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Gemini USD"]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["There are a few more small players in this space. Gemini is a regulated crypto exchange based in NY, USA. It gained prominence as it was launched by the ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winklevoss_twins",children:"Winklesvoss twin"})," who invested heavily in Bitcoin early on."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Similar to the other stable coins, Gemini USD publishes monthly ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://gemini.com/static/dollar/Gemini-Dollar-Examination-Report-4-30-20.pdf",children:"exminations reports"}),"."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The Gemini dollar Accounts are held and maintained at State Street Bank and Trust Company and within a money market fund managed by Goldman Sachs Asset Management, invested only in U.S. Treasury Obligations (including securities issued or guaranteed by the U.S. Treasury where the payment of principal and interest is backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government)"}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Gemini USD seems to be holding collateral only with U.S. treasuries that are fully garanteed by the U.S. government. Which is actually better than putting your money in a bank account (except for the FDCI inssurance) since the government can't default on its own currency."}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Despite being a safer choice, Gemini USD has a very low market cap ($5mn only) and is pretty much illiquid and there are few venues to trade it."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.h2,{id:"stasis-eur",children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#stasis-eur","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,a.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Stasis Eur"]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://stasis.net/",children:"Stasis Eur"})," is an interesting stable coin because the EUR is less represented in this space. The long time for development, the different incompatible versions, and the various libraries; however, might made it ",(0,a.jsx)(e.em,{children:"not"})," very straightforward to grasp. There is a lot going and it's not obvious from where to start."]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Let's start from the beginning."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.h3,{id:"what-is-async",children:[(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#what-is-async","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,a.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"What is Async?"]}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:"There are several articles, books and videos that goes in depth on Async; but I'll give you the short version: If you have a single processor and want to execute two tasks simultaneously (kind of), how would you do it? The solution is to run a little bit of the first task, then switch and run a little bit of the second task, then switch back, etc... until both tasks are complete."}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["This is useful if you want to give the impression that the computer is running both tasks simultaneously and the computer is fast enough to trick the human eye (i.e.: multitasking). Another useful use-case is ",(0,a.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input/output",children:"IO"})," operations. When your program is waiting for a network response, your CPU is sitting idle. In IO bound code, multi threading is the worst throughput you can have. Tasks + async/await will blow away any IO-bound-threadpool you can write your own. threads don't scale. usually (especially on Server side) you have both. you read some data from a connection (IO), then continue processing it on the CPU (json parsing, calculations etc.) and write the result back to the connection (IO again). Tasks + async/await are faster in this case than a pure multi threaded code."}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:`It's the simplicity which makes async/await so appealing. writing a synchronous code which is actually asynchronous. if this is not "high level programing", what is?`}),` `]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["And that's where Rust Async comes in. item.title: The modern web is becoming an unusable, user-hostile wasteland
item.description: Some thoughts about the modern web
item.author: contact@omarabid.com (Abid Omar)

So they do it, and time passes, and another bushy-tailed MBA comes along, and does another study, and concludes that removing another five sesame seeds wouldn\u2019t hurt either, and would save even more money, and so on and so forth, every year or two, the new management trainee looking for ways to save money proposes removing a sesame seed or two, until eventually, they\u2019re shipping hamburger buns with exactly three sesame seeds artfully arranged in a triangle, and nobody buys their hamburgers any more."}),` `]}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,n.jsxs)(e.em,{children:["Joel Spolsky from ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://www.joelonsoftware.com/2007/09/11/theres-no-place-like-127001/",children:"There\u2019s no place like 127.0.0.1"})]})}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"As I keep browsing today's internet, I keep recalling this extract. It's the same thing happening with the modern web: If you add another advertisement to your pages, you generate more revenue. If you track your users better, now you can deliver tailored ads and your conversion rates are higher. If you restrict users from leaving your walled garden ecosystem, now you get all the juice from whatever attention they have."}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The question is: At which point do we reach the breaking point?"}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["And I think the answer is: ",(0,n.jsx)(e.em,{children:"We are very close"}),"."]}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Here are some of these websites, who have managed over time to turn the user experience almost unusable for anyone who doesn't have an account."}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.h2,{id:"facebook",children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"#facebook","aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Facebook"]}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"If you try to open a Facebook page without an account, this is what you get."}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/the-modern-web/dJwcwmJQW8QkFHeMQBKnTC0xspap.png",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/the-modern-web/dJwcwmJQW8QkFHeMQBKnTC0xspap.png",alt:"Screen Shot 2019-11-11 at 6.34.32 PM.png"})})}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"There is a blue header at the top that has the login form. Have you signed up yet?"}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Let's try to scroll a little bit more."}),` `,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"/static/images/blog/the-modern-web/gNR1XozEXRGq8TxxBbtSK60xspap.png",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.img,{src:"/static/images/blog/the-modern-web/gNR1XozEXRGq8TxxBbtSK60xspap.png",alt:"Screen Shot 2019-11-11 at 6.34.55 PM.png"})})}),` `,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[`Wooha! I think Rust is hard to learn but should be manageable for your average software developer given enough persistence."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Once you are over that barrier, you start thinking of building something in Rust. Probably, for the web, or a desktop application, or a mobile application; because that's largely what many developers are building today."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The problem is, in my opinion, the Rust ecosystem is pretty much under-developed at this point. Especially, if you are targeting web, desktop or mobile. The infrastructure is simply not there. The crates have little maintainers, little documentation, no tutorials, and the tooling is just bad."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"So here is how I think this should be approached:"}),` `,(0,i.jsxs)(e.ul,{children:[` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Focus on few angles and crates. For example, a web framework; or a cross-platform native GUI library. The number of these crates should be less than 10."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Documentation should be a priority, with examples and tutorials to get people started using these particular libraries."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Preferably run on latest Rust Stable."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"License the libraries under MIT License to enable commercial use."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"No unsafe code or minimize unsafe code. In general, these libraries should show developers how to write code and follow best practices with Rust."}),` `]}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"For tooling, here is what I'm struggling with:"}),` `,(0,i.jsxs)(e.ul,{children:[` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Very slow compile time. This has been mentioned many times, and I think any speedup will be welcome."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Lifetime visualizer: I think it'll help to have the people who developed the language do this (I think it is a hard problem). This could be a simple CLI app, and developers will jump on making a nice UI output."}),` `]})]});return n?(0,i.jsx)(n,Object.assign({},t,{children:o})):o}var v=y;return I;})(); ;return Component.default;

By deep dive, it means the blog post is considerably long. So it will take time to go through the different examples. The topic we will dive through is specific but we will have to go through various Rust concepts: Ownership/Borrowing, Lifetimes, Unsafe, Sync, Closures, Macros and more. This might be intimidating and I think this is where many developers are put off."}),` `,(0,a.jsx)(e.p,{children:'This article assumes some familiarity with Rust; that is if you have successfully run a "Hello World" program, then you are qualified! If you have struggled with some of the hard concepts then this article could be a good introduction. That might seem like a straightforward thing to do, especially if you are coming from other languages like JavaScript. If we have a variable (and the browser is our sandbox), then we can make it global by attaching it to the ",(0,a.jsx)(e.code,{children:"window"})," object. So if we have ",(0,a.jsx)(e.code,{children:"window.config"}),", we can access (both read and write) the ",(0,a.jsx)(e.code,{children:"config"})," variable from anywhere in our code."]}),` `,(0,a.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["So our problem is we have this ",(0,a.jsx)(e.code,{children:"config"})," object but in Rust. It can be set and initialized somewhere in our program. The initialization bit is important as we will find out later. item.title: The VIM Experience
item.author: contact@omarabid.com (Abid Omar)
item.content:encoded: var Component=(()=>{var s=Object.create;var a=Object.defineProperty;var h=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var d=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var m=Object.getPrototypeOf,g=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var r=t=>a(t,"__esModule",{value:!0});var u=(t,e)=>()=>(e||t((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),p=(t,e)=>{r(t);for(var n in e)a(t,n,{get:e[n],enumerable:!0})},f=(t,e,n)=>{if(e&&typeof e=="object"||typeof e=="function")for(let o of d(e))!g.call(t,o)&&o!=="default"&&a(t,o,{get:()=>e[o],enumerable:!(n=h(e,o))||n.enumerable});return t},y=t=>f(r(a(t!=null?s(m(t)):{},"default",t&&t.__esModule&&"default"in t?{get:()=>t.default,enumerable:!0}:{value:t,enumerable:!0})),t);var c=u((I,l)=>{l.exports=_jsx_runtime});var x={};p(x,{default:()=>w,frontmatter:()=>b});var i=y(c()),b={title:"The VIM Experience",date:"2019-04-27",tags:["vim","productivity"],draft:!1,summary:"7 years journey with VIM",images:[],layout:"PostLayout"};function v(t){let e=Object.assign({blockquote:"blockquote",p:"p",code:"code",a:"a",ul:"ul",li:"li",h4:"h4",span:"span",strong:"strong",img:"img"},t.components),{wrapper:n}=e,o=(0,i.jsxs)(i.Fragment,{children:[(0,i.jsxs)(e.blockquote,{children:[` `,(0,i.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["For the Vim crowd, my ",(0,i.jsx)(e.code,{children:".vimrc"})," file is available on ",(0,i.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://github.com/omarabid/vimrc",children:"Github"}),"."]}),` `]}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"I got introduced to Vim 7 years ago. Getting started with Vim was a challenge. I think it was a typical experience: Vim has a steep learning curve and requires lots of customization to hit that nice spot. There is even a cost to start typing actual text. As I've never been introduced to a Vim-like model, my intuition for a text editor is to just start typing. When you opt for a new experience to increase your productivity, it is hard to be convinced to hit a key to start typing. It seemed counter-intuitive."}),` `,(0,i.jsxs)(e.p,{children:['That made me bail of Vim multiple times. But I always had the inklings to give it another shot. I think a part of it is "jealousy". Seeing other developers wrangling code in unusual ways, I wanted to have that kind of power. Also, ',(0,i.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpal_tunnel_syndrome",children:"carpal tunnel syndrome"})," is real and I needed to relieve my hands of constant switching."]}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"It is fair to say now that I'm comfortable enough with Vim. Vim was a game changer and had a significant impact on my productivity. I can see that the time spent on configuration and customization has been paying off dividends."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"I rely heavily on Vim and though I made it sound like it is all roses; I do have some frustration. The editor has some considerable shortcomings; especially if you are expecting an IDE-like experience. The process of augmenting Vim to be able to support proper code formatting is rather expensive. That's something you get by default in most of the IDEs out there."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"The most annoying of these were:"}),` `,(0,i.jsxs)(e.ul,{children:[` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"You don't get proper language support; even for formatting. The default formatter is very basic and language agnostic. You'll have to install different plugins for different languages."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Usually, there are different competing plugins for any particular language. You'll have to make a decision of what is best for you."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Many plugins require external programs to function. They also need to be able to call these properly from Vim. It can be a challenge to get that working properly and the documentation might be lacking."}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.li,{children:"Syntax checking is still lagging and years behind what most IDEs will offer you. This is, of course, my opinion."}),` `]}),` `,(0,i.jsx)(e.p,{children:"Lately, I've been diving into Rust. So my Vim configuration has been getting accommodated accordingly. It makes this configuration a bit biased, though you can make use of the keyboard shortcuts and other goodies."}),`
